questions.text: A 16-year-old girl comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well. She lives with her parents at home. She says that the relationship with her parents has been strained lately because they "do not approve" of her new boyfriend. She recently became sexually active with her boyfriend and requests a prescription for oral contraception. She does not want her parents to know. She smokes one-half pack of cigarettes daily and does not drink alcohol. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Inform patient that her smoking history disqualifies her for combined oral contraceptives
Discuss all effective contraceptive options
Ask patient to obtain parental consent before discussing any contraceptive options
Recommend an oral contraceptive pill

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Smoking, in general, is a relative contraindication to combined oral contraceptives (COC). It is only an absolute contraindication in patients older than 35 years, but this patient is only 16 years of age. She should be counseled regarding the risks associated with OCP use, specifically in relation to smoking; OCPs are still a viable option for her.

B) CORRECT:

Discussing all effective contraceptive options and providing the patient with unbiased and objective information should be the first step. Parental consent is not required for providing information (all states) to mature minors, nor for prescribing contraceptives (most states).

C) INCORRECT:

Parental consent is not required for providing information about contraceptive options in any state. In most states, parental consent is also not required for prescribing contraceptive drugs to mature minors.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral contraceptive pills are a very common and efficient contraceptive method. However, the patient needs to be informed about all contraceptive options so that both patient and doctor can decide on a suitable contraceptive method together.
questions.hint: As a physician, you should always try to respect privacy, be empathetic, and help in questions of health.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She recently became sexually active with her boyfriend and requests a prescription for an oral contraception. She lives with her parents. She has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 2 years. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate response?

choices.text: "I would recommend performing a Pap smear, since you have become sexually active."
"I would like to discuss the various contraceptive options that are available."
"I would need your parent's permission before I can provide information about contraceptive therapy."
"I cannot prescribe oral contraceptives if you are currently a smoker."
"I would recommend a multiphasic combination of ethinyl estradiol and norgestimate."

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The USPSTF and ACOG recommend annual screening for chlamydia and gonorrhea in sexually active teens, but a Pap smear is not required until the age of 21 years, even if the patient is sexually active.

B) CORRECT:

Discussing the different contraceptive options and providing the patient with unbiased and objective information should be the first step. Parental consent is not required for providing information to mature minors (in any state), nor for prescribing contraceptives (in most states).

C) INCORRECT:

Parental consent is not required in order to provide a minor with information about contraceptive options in any state. In most states, parental consent is also not required for prescribing contraceptive drugs to minors between the ages of 14 and 17 years.

D) INCORRECT:

Smoking, in general, is a relative contraindication to oral contraceptives (OCP). It is only an absolute contraindication in patients older than 35 years, but this patient is only 15. While she should be counseled regarding the risks associated with OCP use, specifically in relation to smoking, OCPs are still a viable option for her.

E) INCORRECT:

Combined oral contraceptive therapy is a very effective and commonly used contraceptive method. However, the patient should be informed about all contraceptive options so that both patient and doctor can decide on a suitable contraceptive method together.
questions.hint: As a physician, you should always try to respect privacy, be empathetic, and offer appropriate counseling.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl presents to the emergency department confused, irritable, and disheveled. Her confusion resolves within an hour, and she recalls being at a party where most of the teens were ingesting random, unidentified pills. She says that she attends parties every weekend, and her parents have been "hassling" her to cut back on the partying. She usually drives herself to and from the parties. She discloses that her grades have recently slipped, and she is less concerned about her future. She also mentions that she has been missing more and more school.
Which one of the following questions is most important to ask this patient next in order to screen for a substance use disorder?

choices.text: Why do you use drugs?
Do you ever use drugs to relax?
Can you tell me why you’ve been missing so much school?
How many of your friends get high at parties?
Do you understand the dangers of drug use?

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Other questions — about why the patient uses drugs, how many friends get high at parties, why the patient misses school, and what the patient understands about the dangers of drug use — are important, but none of these will identify problematic substance use or help determine a treatment plan.

B) CORRECT:

Adolescents who are suspected of substance use disorder can be quickly screened using the CRAFFT questionnaire, which involves six questions:

• C: Have you ever driven a car while high or ridden in a car with someone who was high?
• R: Do you ever use alcohol or drugs to relax, feel better about yourself, or fit in?
• A: Do you ever use alcohol or drugs when alone?
• F: Do you ever forget things you did while using alcohol or drugs?
• F: Do your family or friends ever tell you to cut back on your drinking or drug use?
• T: Have you ever gotten into trouble while you were using alcohol or drugs?

Adolescents who answer affirmatively to two or more of these questions should be assessed further for substance use disorder, and treatment should be recommended accordingly. Even if an adolescent does not answer affirmatively to any of these questions, CRAFFT can be used as an opportunity for further education on drug use.

Key learning point: When evaluating an adolescent for substance use disorder, the clinician should assess whether the adolescent has ever used drugs or alcohol while driving, gotten into trouble while using, been forgetful after using, been advised by family and friends to cut back, and used drugs or alcohol to relax.

C) INCORRECT:

Other questions — about why the patient uses drugs, how many friends get high at parties, why the patient misses school, and what the patient understands about the dangers of drug use — are important, but none of these will identify problematic substance use or help determine a treatment plan.

D) INCORRECT:

Other questions — about why the patient uses drugs, how many friends get high at parties, why the patient misses school, and what the patient understands about the dangers of drug use — are important, but none of these will identify problematic substance use or help determine a treatment plan.

E) INCORRECT:

Other questions — about why the patient uses drugs, how many friends get high at parties, why the patient misses school, and what the patient understands about the dangers of drug use — are important, but none of these will identify problematic substance use or help determine a treatment plan.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old man requests help with smoking cessation. He has been smoking cigarettes for 3 years, but the frequency increased markedly during the past year. On examination, he smells like smoke, appears disheveled, and seems to be sadder than during previous visits. On further questioning, he reports that he has difficulty sleeping, trouble concentrating, and very little energy; he feels sluggish and is failing in school. He denies current suicidal ideation.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Varenicline
Fluoxetine
Nicotine gum
Bupropion
Nicotine patch

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Varenicline helps with smoking cessation but does not treat depression. Neuropsychiatric symptoms, including depression, have been associated with its use.

B) INCORRECT:

Fluoxetine is a suitable and effective medication to treat depression in adolescents, but it does not treat tobacco use.

C) INCORRECT:

Nicotine gum and the nicotine patch are effective approaches to support tobacco cessation, but they will not treat symptoms of depression. They also do not support cessation as well as bupropion in the setting of depression. In a large randomized trial of smokers, bupropion and nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) were associated with similar rates of tobacco abstinence overall. However, in those with a history of depression, bupropion led to significantly higher rates of abstinence than NRT. Of note, there is limited evidence on the use of bupropion for tobacco cessation in adolescents <18 years of age.

D) CORRECT:

This patient is requesting help with his tobacco use, but he also has features of depression. The antidepressant bupropion is effective for the management of both diagnoses.

Key learning point: Bupropion should be strongly considered in patients who request help with tobacco use and have comorbid depression.

E) INCORRECT:

Nicotine gum and the nicotine patch are effective approaches to support tobacco cessation, but they will not treat symptoms of depression. They also do not support cessation as well as bupropion in the setting of depression. In a large randomized trial of smokers, bupropion and nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) were associated with similar rates of tobacco abstinence overall. However, in those with a history of depression, bupropion led to significantly higher rates of abstinence than NRT. Of note, there is limited evidence on the use of bupropion for tobacco cessation in adolescents <18 years of age.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old boy with gastroesophageal reflux disease presents for an annual visit. Interval history reveals that he failed two classes this year and will need to attend summer school for the first time. In addition, he was suspended for 3 days last month because of disruptive behavior at a school dance. When interviewed privately, he reveals that he was drinking alcohol before he got into an altercation with another student at the dance.
Upon further questioning, he says that he sometimes has five or six drinks per evening. He answers “yes” to four out of six questions on the CRAFFT questionnaire and also reports that he requires an increasingly higher number of drinks to obtain the same level of intoxication.
Despite considering himself a “social drinker,” he has started to drink after school as a “pick-me-up” before starting homework. He reports that his best friend has concerns about his drinking but that he himself is not concerned.
In addition to counseling this patient about not driving after drinking, which one of the following statements is the best approach for counseling this patient?

choices.text: Would you be willing to begin treatment with a medication called disulfiram? It will help you stop drinking.
Your health problems and your problems at school appear to be related to your alcohol intake. Do you understand that denial is common in alcohol use disorder?
I’m worried about your drinking and think that your health problems and your problems at school will improve if you decrease your alcohol intake. What are your goals?
I recommend you begin attending Alcoholics Anonymous meetings. These meetings are very effective for alcohol use disorder. Would you be willing to attend?
You appear to have alcohol use disorder and need help now. I recommend that you get inpatient treatment. Would you be able to start next week?

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Recommending a detoxification program — or other services (such as psychosocial treatment, medication, or mutual help groups) — would be premature. The clinician should make the patient aware of such options but only after a discussion about behavior change.

B) INCORRECT:

Confronting unhealthy defenses, such as denial, at the outset of the discussion or providing a “simple” referral to treatment could be viewed negatively by the patient. Threats of negative health consequences are often experienced as argumentative and judgmental and are therefore counterproductive.

C) CORRECT:

People with unhealthy patterns of substance use often present with problems that go unrecognized as being related to the substance use. To help address this, clinicians should use the Screening to Brief Intervention (S2BI) tool: https://nida.nih.gov/s2bi/#/ (or something similar) to ask all adolescents at their annual visit how frequently they have used various substances in the past year. If the answer is at least monthly for any substance, a more detailed assessment should be done using a validated tool such as CRAFFT (Car, Relax, Alone, Forget, Family/Friends, Trouble).

Once a diagnosis has been obtained, the clinician should decide whether the patient needs to enter a detoxification program right away. In this case, the patient has alcohol use disorder, and abstaining from all alcohol use would be best, but he has not expressed a desire to change his drinking, and he is not at immediate risk. Recommending a detoxification program — or other services (such as psychosocial treatment, medication, or mutual help groups) — would therefore be premature. The clinician should make the patient aware of such options but only after a discussion about behavior change.

During the course of the conversation, the clinician should express concern for the patient’s health and ask open-ended questions while providing clear information about the advantages of abstaining from alcohol or working toward that by cutting down. To increase the chances of this conversation being successful, the clinician can incorporate principles of motivational interviewing.

This nonjudgmental method of counseling communicates acceptance rather than reproach and supports conditions for change. One important aim is to encourage the patient to believe in the possibility of change while also making clear that the change is up to him and that the clinician is there as a partner to help with that change. If an adolescent is at risk of harming themselves, the parents or guardians should be involved as well.

If the patient decides to try abstinence, the clinician should assess the risk of alcohol withdrawal, including the risk of delirium tremens, and recommend the appropriate level of care.

Lifestyle changes are difficult to make, and patients usually take some time to muster the energy and commitment needed to give up an ingrained habit like drinking. Clinicians might feel frustrated by these delays and argue even more fervently for change, but this approach often backfires. Confronting unhealthy defenses, such as denial, at the outset of the discussion or providing a “simple” referral to treatment could be viewed negatively by the patient. Threats of negative health consequences are often experienced as argumentative and judgmental and are therefore counterproductive. A better approach is to provide education and foster an alliance that can be used to motivate change.

Key learning point: The best intervention for people with alcohol use disorder who do not recognize their drinking as a problem is to express concern and provide clear advice regarding cutting back and abstinence.
Image Description:

– Precontemplation stage (*): The individual denies or is unaware there is a problem
– Contemplation stage: The individual is aware there is a problem but not willing to make a change
– Preparation stage: The individual is ready/preparing to make a change
– Action stage: The individual demonstrates a change in behavior
– Maintenance stage: The individual maintains the behavioral changes. This may be permanent, or they may relapse.
– Relapse: The behavioral changes are reversed. The cycle may restart.

D) INCORRECT:

Recommending a detoxification program — or other services (such as psychosocial treatment, medication, or mutual help groups) — would be premature. The clinician should make the patient aware of such options but only after a discussion about behavior change.

E) INCORRECT:

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her friend in a confused, irritable, and disheveled state. Her confusion resolves within an hour, and she recalls being at a party where most of her peers were ingesting random, unidentified pills. She says that she attends parties every weekend, and her parents have been "hassling" her to cut back on the partying. She usually drives herself to and from the parties. She discloses that her grades have recently slipped, and she is less concerned about her future. She also mentions that she has been missing more and more school. Which of the following is the most appropriate question by the physician to screen for a substance use disorder?

choices.text: "Why have you been missing so much school?"
"How many of your friends get high at parties?"
"Do you ever use drugs to relax?"
"Do you understand the dangers of drug use?"
"Why do you use drugs?"

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Asking about reasons for poor school attendance does not effectively screen for a substance use disorder. Moreover, if a motivational interviewing approach is followed at a later stage of the conversation, a better question to elicit self-reflection would be “How do you feel about your school attendance?”.

B) INCORRECT:

Understanding drug use among peers can provide insight into social influences, drug use normalization, and access to substances, and help guide interventions for adolescents. However, this question does not effectively screen for a substance use disorder. Moreover, from a motivational interviewing perspective, it is better to focus on the patient's thoughts rather than their friends' behaviors (e.g., “What are your thoughts on drug use at the parties you attend?”).

C) CORRECT:

The CRAFFT questionnaire involves six questions:

• C: Have you ever driven a car while high or ridden in a car with someone who was high?
• R: Do you ever use alcohol or drugs to relax, feel better about yourself, or fit in?
• A: Do you ever use alcohol or drugs when alone?
• F: Do you ever forget things you did while using alcohol or drugs?
• F: Do your family or friends ever tell you to cut back on your drinking or drug use?
• T: Have you ever gotten into trouble while you were using alcohol or drugs?

Adolescents who answer affirmatively to ≥ 2 of these questions should be assessed further for substance use disorder, and treatment should be recommended accordingly. Even if an adolescent does not answer affirmatively to any of these questions, CRAFFT can be used as an opportunity for further education on drug use.

D) INCORRECT:

This question can sound accusatory and put the patient on the defensive. A different question should be asked to screen for a substance use disorder. Moreover, if a motivational interviewing approach is followed at a later stage of the conversation, a better question to elicit self-reflection would be “What are your thoughts on how drug use might affect one's health?”.

E) INCORRECT:

An open-ended question on why the patient uses drugs is important but is not the most appropriate initial question to screen for a substance use disorder, for which a closed-ended question is preferred.
questions.hint: Adolescents who are suspected of substance use disorder can be quickly screened using the CRAFFT questionnaire.

She smokes half a pack of cigarettes daily and does not drink alcohol. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination is normal. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Instead, under the mature minor doctrine, clinicians assess each adolescent’s capacity on a case-by-case basis, and no parental consent is required if the youth demonstrates understanding.

Key learning point: Sexually active minors should be offered confidential counseling on all effective contraceptive options without requiring parental consent.
